name: Senna
Relationship: Compare: KALI-CARB.; JALAPA. Antidotes: NUX; CHAM.

Urine: Specific gravity and density increased; hyperazoturia, oxaluria, phosphaturia, and acetonuria
Stool: Liver enlarged and tender, stools hard and dark, with loss of appetite, coated tongue, bad taste, and weakness
Burning in rectum, with strangury of bladder
Fluid yellowish, with pinching pains before

details: Is of much use in infantile colics when the child seems to be FULL OF WIND. Oxaluria, with excess of urea; increased specific gravity. Where the system is broken down, bowels constipated, muscular weakness, and waste of nitrogenous materials, Senna will act as a tonic. Ebullitions of blood at night. ACETONAEMIA, prostration, fainting, constipation with colic and flatulence. Liver enlarged and tender.
